an7.63:1.1: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, went to the home of the householder Anāthapiṇḍika, where he sat on the seat spread out.
an7.63:1.2: Now at that time people in Anāthapiṇḍika’s home were making a dreadful racket.
an7.63:1.3: Then the householder Anāthapiṇḍika went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him,
an7.63:2.1: “Householder, what’s with the people making that dreadful racket in your home? You’d think it was fishermen hauling in a catch!”
an7.63:2.2: “Sir, that’s my daughter-in-law Sujātā. She’s been brought here from a wealthy family.
an7.63:2.3: She doesn’t obey her mother-in-law or father-in-law or her husband. And she does not honor, respect, esteem, and venerate the Buddha.”
an7.63:3.1: Then the Buddha addressed Sujātā, saying,
an7.63:3.3: “Yes, sir,” she replied. She went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to her:
an7.63:4.1: “Sujātā, a man can have seven kinds of wife.
an7.63:4.3: A wife like a killer, a wife like a thief, a wife like a lord, a wife like a mother, a wife like a sister, a wife like a friend, and a wife like a bondservant.
an7.63:4.4: These are the kinds of wife that a man can have.
an7.63:4.5: Which one of these are you?”
an7.63:4.6: “Sir, I don’t understand the detailed meaning of what the Buddha has said in brief.
an7.63:4.7: Please teach me this matter so I can understand the detailed meaning.”
an7.63:4.8: “Well then, Sujātā, listen and pay close attention, I will speak.”
an7.63:5.1: “With a mind full of hate and no kindness,
an7.63:5.2: lusting for others, looking down on her husband,
an7.63:5.3: she longs to murder him who paid the price for her.
an7.63:5.4: A man’s wife of this sort
an7.63:5.5: is called a wife and a killer.
an7.63:6.1: A woman’s husband earns his wealth
an7.63:6.2: by applying oneself to a profession, trade, or farming.
an7.63:6.3: And even if it’s only a little, she wants to take it.
an7.63:6.4: A man’s wife of this sort
an7.63:6.5: is called a wife and a thief.
an7.63:7.1: She’s an idle glutton who doesn’t want to work.
an7.63:7.2: Her words are harsh, fierce, and rude.
an7.63:7.3: She rules over him, though he rises early.
an7.63:7.4: A man’s wife of this sort
an7.63:7.5: is called a wife and a lord.
an7.63:8.2: looking after her husband like a mother her child.
an7.63:8.3: She keeps the wealth that he has earned secure.
an7.63:8.4: A man’s wife of this sort
an7.63:8.5: is called a wife and a mother.
an7.63:9.2: as a younger sister respects her elder.
an7.63:9.3: Conscientious, she does what her husband says.
an7.63:9.4: A man’s wife of this sort
an7.63:9.5: is called a wife and a sister.
an7.63:10.2: like one reunited with a long-lost friend.
an7.63:10.4: A man’s wife of this sort
an7.63:10.5: is called a wife and a friend.
an7.63:11.1: She has no anger <j>when threatened with violence by the rod.
an7.63:11.3: she endures her husband and does what he says.
an7.63:11.4: A man’s wife of this sort
an7.63:11.5: is called a wife and a bondservant.
an7.63:12.1: The kinds of wives here called
an7.63:12.3: immoral, harsh, and lacking regard for others,
an7.63:12.4: when their body breaks up they set course for hell.
an7.63:13.1: But the kinds of wives here called
an7.63:13.3: steadfast in their own morality, <j>restrained for a long time,
an7.63:13.4: when their body breaks up <j>they set course for a good place.
an7.63:14.1: Sujātā, these are the seven kinds of wife that a man can have.
an7.63:14.2: Which one of these are you?”
an7.63:14.3: “Sir, from this day forth may the Buddha remember me as a wife like a bondservant.”
